Investigation.name: VENERA 13
Investigation.description:
Venera 13 and 14 were identical spacecraft built to take advantage of the 1981 Venus launch opportunity and launched 5 days apart. The Venera 13 mission consisted of a flyby carrier bus and an attached descent craft with a launch mass of 4363 kg. The bus mission is described here.
Venera 13 launched on 30 October 1981 at 06:04:00 UT on a Proton-K booster from Baikonur Cosmodrome (Tyuratam).
The four month cruise to Venus involved two mid-course corrections on 10 November 1981 and 21 February 1982. The descent module separated on 27 February 1982 and plunged into the Venus atmosphere on 1 March 1982. As it flew by Venus, the flyby carrier bus acted as a data relay for the brief life of the descent module and then continued on a heliocentric orbit. As a test to provide engineering data for the upcoming flyby of Comet Halley by the Vega spacecraft, the engine was fired on 10 June and 14 October 1982. The platform transmitted data from interplanetary space until at least 25 April 1983.
